commit_message:
Client Changes for Guest Log File Retrieval

Implements log file retrieval from the guest agent.  The contents
of the log file are pushed up to a swift container as a series of
objects that represent a subset of the lines in the log.

The following trove CLI commands are implemented:

trove log-list <instance>         : lists log files available on guest
trove log-enable <instance> <log> : enables writing to log file
trove log-disable <instance> <log>: disables writing to log file
trove log-publish <instance> <log>: publishes updates to swift container
trove log-discard <instance> <log>: discards published logs
trove log-tail <instance> <log>   : displays last lines of log
trove log-save <instance> <log>   : saves the entire log to a file

subject: Adding a tool for querying volume paths
commit_message:
Adding a tool for querying volume paths

There are several os-brick APIs that were added to connectors
recently that allow for querying of volume paths
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/199764/). This patch creates
a tool to simplify the use of these APIs for an
admin/developer/tester/CI doing tasks involving attach/detach who
wishes to verify that volume paths are not left on a system after
a detach.

This tool exposes two APIs:

* get_volume_paths
    - Get the volume paths associated with a specific volume.

* get_all_volume_paths
    - Get all the volume paths on a system for a specified
      connector protocol.

These APIs are of use in a testing or developement environment
when many attach and detach operations are being done and
verification of proper functionality is desired.

The use of this tool has benefits in scenarios where many attaches
and detaches will be occuring. There have been cases where some APIs
in Nova and Cinder have ended up leaving volume paths behind on a
system. A developer or tester could manually check the volume paths
but this can become time consuming if multiple tests need to be done
to reproduce the issue or if the issue only occurs intermittently. It
is also useful because there are many different connector protocols
that can be used by Nova and Cinder and some store volume path
information differently than others. The os-brick APIs for fetching
path information make it easy to get volume path information. This
tool then makes it easy to call the os-brick APIs with the needed
information to get the volume path information.

Cases where testing with this tool is useful:

* Single attach/detach
* Multiple attach/detach sequence
* Live-Migration scenarios
* Any action involving attach or detach in Cinder or Nova

Example usage of tool:

<System(s) doing tasks involving attach/detach>

1. An admin/developer/tester/CI wants to ensure that attach and
   detaches are not leaving behind volume paths on the system.

2. Run query_volume_paths tool on the system where path information
   is desired after a volume attach has occured. Use the
   get_volume_paths API to get path information for the specific
   volume. The get_all_volume_paths API can also be used before the
   attach if a snapshot of all paths on the system is desired.

3. Perform the test involving attach/detach.

4. Run query_volume_paths tool again on the system after detaching
   the volume. Use the get_all_volume_paths API to get all path
   information. Compare the before and after outputs to see if any
   paths for the volume were left behind.

The output from steps 2 and 4 can be processed in whatever way is
desired. This could be another script that determines if the returned
paths look good or it could be manually checked. The tool itself just
gives a way to easily get the path information from os-brick.

One way to use the collected data would be:

* Save volume path information for the volume after attaching.
* Save volume path information after detaching.
* Compare before and after volume path information to ensure the
  known volume paths from before the detach are now gone from
  the system.

This tool does require the python-cinderclient so that it can request
connection information from drivers but it appears to be the only way
to get the needed information currently. Ideally python-cinderclient
would already be installed on the systems that attach/detach tests
are being done on.

Partially Implements: blueprint brick-fetch-paths

subject: Allow sourcing apt_key from ansible host or URL
commit_message:
Allow sourcing apt_key from ansible host or URL

This change allows deployers to specify locally sourced apt keys
on the ansible host or URL rather than requiring all apt keys to
be downloaded from upstream keyservers.

The current implementation requires that all containers and hosts
we deploy to have an internet connection to download apt keys for
the various repos. This change allows the user to source apt keys
from the deployment host like for example:

galera_client_gpg_keys:
  - key_name: 'mariadb'
    data: "{{ lookup('file', '/etc/openstack_deploy/keys/mariadb.gpg') }}"
    hash_id: '0xcbcb082a1bb943db'
  - key_name: 'percona-xtrabackup'
    keyserver: 'hkp://keyserver.ubuntu.com:80'
    fallback_keyserver: 'hkp://p80.pool.sks-keyservers.net:80'
    hash_id: '0x1c4cbdcdcd2efd2a'

so this enables fully offline package installation.

subject: Reduce keystone cache expiration time
commit_message:
Reduce keystone cache expiration time

This commit removes the keystone_cache_expiration_time variable,
allowing deployers to override using standard config overrides.

Additionally, we /temporarily/ disable catalog caching in
keystone.conf.j2 to unblock our master gate.

Note that this change is necessary as we have been experiencing
fairly consistent gate failures in master where the tempest role is
unable to upload an image to glance.  This causes the tempest run to
fail since the expected image is not available.  This upstream keystone
review [1] introduced a change to add catalog caching, and what we are
actually seeing is glance failing to upload the image (or create the
necessary directory in swift) as the object-store endpoint is not in
the catalog which it gets back from keystone.  When this happens we are
presumably hitting a stale cache entry which will not expire for 5400
seconds (the old value of keystone_cache_expiration_time).

For some additional information (as provided by dolphm), it looks like
endpoint updates invalidate portions of the dogpile cache but not all.
There is a fix in flight [2] to address this.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/215212/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/271536/

UpgradeImpact
Related-bug: #1537617

Change-Id: I3b2a833a3e96a3b5deac76052eed480ddcb6175d
(cherry picked from commit c0fa60b3d66ea60cd8a611d72c54fddf5b0e94eb)

the relational DB to make sure the configuration is persistent.

And then plugin updates the records in distributed NoSQL server.

Finally, the transaction of relational DB is commited and the plugin
function is returned with the correct DB object.

If any exception throws in the procedure described above, the relational
DB transaction will be rolled back.

Test Case One:
Kill etcd server when operating the networks. The data is syncronized
between relational DB and etcd server.

Test Case Two:
Concurrently creates 10 network, 10 subnets, 10 routers and 10 instances
to connect to each network and 10 floating-ip allocations for each instance.
Finally, it works for all the instances to be connected via external net.

subject: Limit max service workers by RAM
commit_message:
Limit max service workers by RAM

Intoduce the worker RAM ratio to define the total RAM every single
worker of all service types may consume. More services share the
same node, more RAM ratio should be given to the workers.
The default value assumes there are 20 different types of workers
limited by 100Mb each (or 10 types by 200Mb and so on).

(tl;dr)
Without this fix, we use hardcoded thresholds for service
workers (process/eventlet based) of 16 processes. And for rabbit -
of 100 threads. While the actual values for workers are evaluated
as only CPUs based, with the hardcoded thresholds applied.

This is a problem as the limiting global tresholds must depend on the
physical RAM as well. We don't want 16 workers for an 8CPU, 1G RAM node
to be the same as for an 8CPU & 128G RAM one. Note, that this problem
has nothing to the custom service_workers configurable per each service
in hiera. The global threshold applies only when those are not defined
as well.

The solution is to introduce the workers_ratio (configurable in hiera).
This represents the average workers-to-RAM ratio for a multi process
workers of each known type. The default value is 2000, which is like
10 generic workers of different services to consume 200M each,
or the same as 20 workers X 100M, if there are 20 distinct services.

The workers_ratio serves as an argument for a new global treshold
function limiting the maximum amount of workers for the each distinct
service type. So, there will be no more hardcoded limits of 16 / 100.
Instead, those will be evaluated as a function F(RAM, workers_ratio).
Examples:
F(1G, 2000)=1 global workers threshold for processes;
F(2G, 2000)=2;
F(8G, 2000)=5;
F(64G, 2000)=F(128G, 2000)=30

And the service_workers will be evaluated as:
$threads = min($workers_max,max(12*$physicalprocessorcount,30))
$processess = min(max($::processorcount, 2), $workers_max)
Instead as it was before:
$threads = min(100,max(12*$physicalprocessorcount,30))
$processess = min(max($::processorcount, 2), 16)

(Note that the effective threads value will be doubled for the rabbitmq
thread workers. We don't change other thread workers, like apache2, as they
are implemented to depend on the available RAM already)

Also, add missing noop tests for service workers, address todo for the
rabbitmq in the openstack::nova::controller class (no more needed as
was removed).

Closes-bug: #1529096

Change-Id: Ib90838cff05419d824d064e93b13b627b5a07fea

subject: Unit test for checking cross-version migrations compatibility
commit_message:
Unit test for checking cross-version migrations compatibility

Future incompatible changes in database schema, like removing,
renaming columns and tables can break rolling upgrades (upgrades when
Keystone services are run at different versions simultaneously). This
patch bans schema changes which cause incompatibilities - specifically
drops and alters. Note that it is not bullet-proof - some incompatible
schema changes like adding incompatible constraints may still get through.

Closes-Bug: #1509944
